title: DSM-5 Criteria for Bipolar Disorder
description: Diagnostic criteria for bipolar disorder based on DSM-5. Evaluates criteria for manic episodes, hypomanic episodes, and major depressive episodes to determine bipolar I, bipolar II, or other specified bipolar disorders.

parameters.name: elevated_expansive_irritable_mood
parameters.description: Elevated, expansive, or irritable mood present

parameters.name: increased_activity_energy
parameters.description: Abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy

parameters.name: decreased_need_sleep
parameters.description: Decreased need for sleep (feels rested after only 3 hours)

parameters.name: more_talkative
parameters.description: More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking

parameters.name: flight_of_ideas
parameters.description: Flight of ideas or racing thoughts

parameters.name: distractibility
parameters.description: Distractibility (attention easily drawn to unimportant stimuli)

parameters.name: increased_goal_directed_activity
parameters.description: Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation

parameters.name: excessive_risky_behavior
parameters.description: Excessive involvement in risky activities with high potential for painful consequences

parameters.name: substance_medical_cause
parameters.description: Episode NOT better explained by substance use or medical condition

parameters.name: history_major_depressive_episode
parameters.description: History of at least one major depressive episode

ranges.interpretation: Does not meet DSM-5 criteria for Bipolar Disorder. Consider other mood disorders, substance-induced conditions, or refer for comprehensive psychiatric evaluation if clinical concerns persist.
Meets criteria for a hypomanic episode. If history of major depressive episode exists, consider Bipolar II Disorder. Requires comprehensive evaluation for full bipolar disorder assessment.

Meets criteria for a manic episode, indicating Bipolar I Disorder. Requires immediate psychiatric evaluation and treatment. Consider hospitalization if psychotic features or significant functional impairment present.
Meets criteria for Bipolar II Disorder (hypomanic episode + major depressive episode history). Requires specialized psychiatric treatment including mood stabilizers and psychotherapy.

references: American Psychiatric Association. Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders: DSM-5. 5th ed. Washington, DC: American Psychiatric Association; 2013.

Youngstrom EA, Birmaher B, Findling RL. Pediatric bipolar disorder: validity, phenomenology, and recommendations for diagnosis. Bipolar Disord. 2008;10(1 Pt 2):194-214. doi: 10.1111/j.1399-5618.2007.00563.x.

Angst J, Azorin JM, Bowden CL, et al. Prevalence and characteristics of undiagnosed bipolar disorders in patients with a major depressive episode. Arch Gen Psychiatry. 2011;68(8):791-8. doi: 10.1001/archgenpsychiatry.2011.87.
formula: Diagnostic evaluation based on DSM-5 criteria: Core symptoms (elevated mood + increased activity/energy) + ≥3 additional symptoms + duration requirements + functional impact + exclusion of substance/medical causes. Manic episode (≥7 days/hospitalization) = Bipolar I; Hypomanic episode (4-6 days) + depressive history = Bipolar II.
notes: This is a diagnostic aid for clinical evaluation, not a substitute for comprehensive psychiatric assessment.
Manic episodes require ≥7 days duration or hospitalization; hypomanic episodes require 4-6 days.
DSM-5 added 'increased activity/energy' as core criterion alongside mood symptoms.
Bipolar I requires only one manic episode; Bipolar II requires hypomanic + depressive episodes.
Mixed features specifier can be applied to manic, hypomanic, or depressive episodes.
Consider cyclothymic disorder for subsyndromal symptoms over ≥2 years.
Substance-induced mood episodes and medical conditions must be ruled out.
Risk assessment for suicide and psychotic features is essential in acute episodes.
